title: 107_s2865
content:
The Fort Sumter National Monument in South Carolina was established in 1948 to commemorate historic events, including the first engagement of the Civil War. Fort Moultrie, site of the first defeat of the British in the Revolutionary War, was acquired by the Federal Government in 1960. Since then, it has been administered by the National Park Service as part of the Fort Sumter National Monument without a clear management mandate or established boundary. Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie are important sites in the protection of Charleston Harbor and the US coastal defense system. Fort Moultrie uniquely preserves the history of US coastal defense from 1776 to 1947. Sullivan's Island Life Saving Station, built in 1896, is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

(1) Charleston Light - refers to the Charleston Light and associated land located between Sullivan's Island Life Saving Station and the mean low water mark.
(2) Map - the map titled "Boundary Map, Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie National Historical Park", dated November 30, 2000.
(3) Park - Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie National Historical Park established by section 4(a).
(4) Secretary - the Secretary of the Interior.
(5) State - the State of South Carolina. The Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie National Historical Park is established to preserve historical values and cultural resources. The boundary of the Park includes land, water, and submerged land depicted on a map available for public inspection. The Secretary may acquire land within the Park boundaries by donation. The Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie National Historical Park can acquire land and personal property through donation, purchase, exchange, or transfer from another Federal agency. State-owned land within the Park boundaries must be acquired by donation only. The Secretary, through the Director, is responsible for the administration of the Park. The Secretary, through the Director of the National Park Service, administers the Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie National Historical Park in accordance with applicable laws. This includes interpreting historical events such as the Battle of Sullivan's Island and the bombardment of Fort Sumter. The curr_chunk discusses the events related to Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie during the Civil War, the development of the coastal defense system in the US from Revolutionary War to World War II, and the lives of workers, soldiers, prisoners, and captive Africans associated with the forts. The Secretary may determine the significance of quarantine houses near Fort Moultrie in the 18th Century and enter into cooperative agreements to preserve them. The Secretary of Transportation will transfer administrative jurisdiction over the Charleston Light to the Secretary for inclusion in the Park, with the condition that necessary repairs and improvements are made. The improvements will be limited to providing utility service and maintaining the existing structures and historic landscape. Additionally, existing laws will be repealed. SEC. 6. REPEAL OF EXISTING LAW. Section 2 of the Joint Resolution establishing the Fort Sumter National Monument in South Carolina is repealed. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Appropriations are authorized to carry out this Act.
